title: Leicester’s fast start continues as James Maddison sinks Spurs with late stunner
text:
Leicester have not been bashful about their lofty ambitions for this season and there is certainly no need for them to set their sights lower after they emerged from this high-class showdown with all three points. This was a thrilling, breathtaking contest featuring fine play by both teams, an exceptional goal by Harry Kane, two goals disallowed by VAR, a terrific equaliser by Ricardo Pereira and a late strike by James Maddison that can only do Leicester good as they strive to upset the Premier League’s established order again.

Tottenham will feature plenty in the highlights but ultimately left deflated, having let another lead slip on the road.

Leicester 2-1 Tottenham: Premier League – live reaction! Read more

It was not hard to detect discordant clanks in the mood music around Spurs going into this game. Mauricio Pochettino had made no effort to mask his anger with the way his team frittered away a two-goal lead during Wednesday’s Champions League excursion to Olympiakos. Spurs’ away form in the Premier League was even more of an irritant, his term winless on their travels since beating Fulham in January. They looked on course to improve their record when Kane put them in front with a remarkable finish in the first half, but the visitors proved unable to suppress a thrilling fightback from Brendan Rodgers’ team.

Pochettino made six changes to the Spurs lineup that had started in Greece – with Christian Eriksen demoted to the bench, Dele Alli omitted from the squad and Hugo Lloris away on paternity leave, meaning Paulo Gazzaniga started in goal. The manager must have been satisfied with the start made by his revamped side, who swarmed over the hosts from the outset. What followed was a contest of top-class intensity and when the opening goal came, it was extraordinary.

It stated when Erik Lamela threaded a pass through to Heung-min Son, who backheeled into the path of Kane. A shunt in the back from the retreating Caglar Söyüncü unbalanced Kane and the striker was falling as he beat Jonny Evans on the edge of the area. Kane was practically horizontal when Kasper Schmeichel rushed out to meet him but the striker’s instinct overrode any inclination to claim a penalty and he instead brought down his right leg on the ball in a chopping motion, hitting it in the ground and over the goalkeeper. It was marvellous improvisation.

Facebook Twitter Pinterest Harry Kane scores to give Tottenham the first-half lead, despite having slipped over in the area. Photograph: Andrew Boyers/Action Images via Reuters

All of which rather sickened Leicester, who had celebrated taking an apparent lead a quarter of an hour earlier only for the goal to be expunged following a VAR review. The decision was a correct and came as a mighty relief to Gazzaniga, whose failure to hold a shot by Youri Tielemans enabled Ayoze Pérez to set up Wilfred Ndidi. But Pérez turned out to have been offside when Tielemans opened fire.

Tottenham had been the first to threaten. Lamela, conniving at the tip of the visitors’ midfield diamond, sent a neat pass through to Son, who dragged a shot wide of the far post from 10 yards. Kane’s first effort came a minute later, but it was a banal one from 20 yards that Schmeichel caught without fuss.

Banality, though, had no place in the rest of this game, which was played with exhilarating tempo, power and offensive intent. Paul Tierney did well to help the players keep the gripping action on the right side of the law, although the home crowd reckoned Moussa Sissoko should have been sent off rather than cautioned after taking the ball and Maddison with a two-footed challenge in the first half.

Spurs went into the break in front but knew the game remained very much in the balance. Tielemans underlined the danger posed by the home side when he released Jamie Vardy early in the second half. Jan Vertonghen did well to keep up with the striker and get a nick on his shot, allowing Gazzaniga to make a plunging save. Danny Rose tidied up before Pérez could pounce. Moments later Son should have increased Spurs’ lead on the counterattack but fluffed his chance after being put through by Harry Winks.

Play continued to hurtle to and fro until Serge Aurier celebrated a ferocious strike into the bottom of the net near the hour. But Son had been offside by a matter of millimetres in the buildup, so VAR did its thing again.

Then, in the 70th minute, Pereira scored a goal with which no one could quibble. It originated in another slick Leicester attack, with Maddison and Harvey Barnes involved before Vardy fizzed a low pass from the left to Pereira, who rammed the ball into the net.

Maddison seized victory for the home team by collecting a pass from Hamza Choudhury and lashing a low shot into the net from over 20 yards.
description: Goals from Ricardo Pereira and James Maddison sealed the points as Leicester won 2-1 against Tottenham, who went ahead through Harry Kane
